title: EGS launch team looking forward to working with Artemis II crew
summary: NASA Exploration Ground Systems (EGS) have been preparing and planning for the Artemis II launch since before the flight crew was announced on April 3. Teams at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC) in Florida are looking forward to working closely with the four astronauts who will be the first to fly to the Moon in over 50 years.

title: Apex to launch first satellite in 2024
summary: Small satellite manufacturer Apex will launch its first satellite next year as a demonstration of its capabilities as it prepares for large-scale production.

title: Virgin Orbit formally enters bankruptcy, seeking a buyer
summary: Branson further cements his position as a "senior" creditor.

title: BREAKING! Virgin Orbit Files For Bankruptcy
summary: Virgin Orbit has filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

title: Virgin Orbit files for bankruptcy
summary: Launch company Virgin Orbit filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy April 4, having failed to achieve financial orbit after burning through more than $1 billion.

title: Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit files for bankruptcy, to seek buyer
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit Holdings (VORB.O) filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Tuesday after the satellite launch company failed to secure the long-term funding needed to help it recover from a January rocket failure.

title: All of a sudden, NASA’s return to the Moon feels rather real
summary: "Artemis II is more than a mission to the Moon and back."

title: Thuraya invests in Astrocast’s LEO constellation
summary: Thuraya is providing Swiss small satellite operator Astrocast a $17.5 million financial lifeline in a deal that marks the Emirati company’s first investment in a low Earth orbit constellation.

title: Lockheed Martin selected by Australia for military satcom project
summary: Lockheed Martin was selected as the “preferred bidder” for a multibillion-dollar Australian military project to build military communications satellites and supporting infrastructure.

title: Using JWST, scientists observe silicate clouds and measure the temperature of exoplanets
summary: With help from the joint NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope, two teams of scientists have made groundbreaking, first-of-their-kind discoveries on two exoplanets. One team utilized the immense power of Webb’s Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) and Near-Infrared Spectrograph (NIRSpec) instruments to observe and characterize clouds and molecules in the atmosphere of an exoplanet located 40 light-years away.
